content.question:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The complete photoelectron spectrum of elemental phosphorus is shown below.

A. On the graph, circle the peak(s) that correspond(s) to the valence electrons of the phosphorus atom.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The complete photoelectron spectrum of elemental phosphorus is shown below.

A. On the graph, circle the peak(s) that correspond(s) to the valence electrons of the phosphorus atom.

In the spectrum, the peak labeled <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corresponds to electrons with a binding energy of about <math alttext="13,500 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mn>13</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>500</mn><mtext> kJ/mol</mtext></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaaIXaGaaG4mai aacYcacaaI1aGaaGimaiaaicdacaqGGaGaae4AaiaabQeacaqGVaGa aeyBaiaab+gacaqGSbaaaa@433A@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>.

B. Identify the subshell that the electrons occupy in the phosphorus atom.
C. Calculate the minimum frequency of electromagnetic radiation that would be needed to eject an electron from the subshell that you identified in part B.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
